title: Cryo-TEM Imaging of Biomimetic Boron Nitride Single-Digit Nanotubes in Liposome Membranes
content: Fluid systems, in the most general case, can contain a liquid solvent, fully dissolved solutes, and a variety of other structured phases, including micelles, membranes, nanoparticles, nanorods, nanotubes, etc. Determining the spatial distribution of these secondary phases is of critical importance to a number of emerging nanofluidic technologies, ranging from desalination to energy storage. Nanofluidic channels are critical features of these technologies, determining their transport properties and, as a result, their overall performance. Nanotubes are ideal candidates to develop these nanofluidic channels. The nanotube’s tunable dimensions and regular surfaces, with well-defined chemical properties, result in platform from which a range of measurements can be conducted. A nanotube porin approach is one avenue to achieve short channel lengths in a nanofluidic platform. The porin approach embeds short nanotube segments into lipid bilayers, creating biomimetic membranes. Using this method, carbon nanotube porins (CNTPs) ∼10 nm long and ∼1.5 nm in diameter have been synthesized [1]. Boron nitride nanotube porins (BNNTPs) are ideal candidates to advance the study of nanofluidics as their size can be controlled in a manner similar to CNTPs but with notably different surface properties.
